description: The Bluing Bolete displays a brown to reddish-brown cap (5-15 cm) with smooth surface. Pores are yellow to olive-yellow, slowly bruising blue-green when handled - a diagnostic feature. The yellowish stem shows reticulation and also bruises blue. White to pale yellow flesh stains blue when cut, especially near pore surface. This bluing reaction distinguishes it from similar species. Spore print is olive-brown.
habitat: Mycorrhizal with oak and other hardwoods in deciduous and mixed forests. Prefers rich, well-drained soils in mature forests. Common in oak-dominated habitats.
season: Summer through fall (July-October) with peak fruiting in late summer. Appears after warm rains during humid weather.
regions: Oak forests throughout eastern North America
lookalikes: Boletus edulis - white pores, no bluing reaction
Boletus variipes - more dramatic bluing, different range
Tylopilus felleus - pink pores, bitter, no blue
Boletus sensibilis - bruises blue very strongly
safety_notes: EDIBLE: Bluing Bolete is a good edible mushroom with firm texture and mild flavor. The blue-staining reaction is normal and safe - this is NOT an indication of toxicity. Cook thoroughly before eating. The bluing helps distinguish it from non-bluing species like B. edulis.
